Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2011 11:06AM ANA_424 wrote: I was diagnosed in April and remember that OMG thing, although it is mostly gone now. One night in that first week or two, I decided I needed to email some friends who live out of town and let them know what was going on. After I sent the emails, I had this moment when I thought, "Did I just tell them that I have breast cancer? Why would I do that? That is not funny." Then I remembered, "Oh yeah, I DO have breast cancer!" All within the space of a second or two I suppose. It was sort of funny and sort of disconcerting at the same time. Later I decided that when something "big" happens, it can take time for the conscious, subconscious, intellectual, physical, emotional, etc. to all get back in sync.
Posts.Title: It's All So Surreal Rockym calamtykel

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2011 03:41PM ANA_424 wrote: I left a really long post in theÂ "Poll on Sentinel Node Biopsy Pain" this weekend. This did not turn out to be painful for me at all, but it was by far the most stressful part because of all the things I had read. That is why I came back to post my experience. Everyone is different and so are the protocols at different hospitals. I gave some suggestions about who to talk to, questions to ask, what you can do to prepare. Best of luck to everyone. Ann
Posts.Title: Radioactive Injection into Nipple NOT TERRIBLE waynesgirl50 Motherofall6

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2011 05:11PM ANA_424 wrote: I'm sure you will get lots of answers and everyone's story is different. I was diagnosed the end of April. I took 2 weeks off for mastectomy (unilateral) and reconstruction with expander - end of May, beginning of June. I was able to work full time after 2 weeks. I'm now having chemo and planning to work as much as possible. I just took 1/2 day off for first treatment. Granted, I don't have an hour long commute - that would make a difference. I'm also able to work from home if needed, but have not done that much. No radiation for me, which also helps. One other thing to figure out is insurance. If you have it now, if you will have to wait to get it at the new job, etc. You don't want to be dealing with this and have insurance issues, if you can help it. My first thought is - follow your heart. If this is your dream job, see if there is some way you can keep it. You will get through treatment and how great it would be to have your great job to look forward to at the end of it :-). If not, then trust that the right thing will come along when the timing is better. Best of luck to you. Ann
Posts.Title: Job and treatment timeframe yuelin ANA_424

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2011 04:24PM ANA_424 wrote: yuelin - That sounds well thought out. Best wishes to you - with or without the new job! Ann
